section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Gather Materials drawing and writing supplies, Alphabet Cards, Yellow Yaks, Zebra Zooms

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Today we read What Am I? We saw the letter y in the word turkey and the letter z in the word quetzal.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Teach Yy Alphabet Cards Show the Alphabet Cards for letters Yy. Say the letter aloud and have children repeat. This is uppercase Y. The letter Y makes the /y/ sound you hear in the word yo-yo. This is lowercase y. The letter y makes the /y/ sound you hear in yarn.

Teach Zz Alphabet Cards Show the Alphabet Cards for the letters Zz. Say the letter aloud and have children repeat. This is uppercase Z. The letter Z makes the /z/ sound you hear in the word zipper. This is lowercase z. The letter z makes the /z/ sound you hear in zebra.
Explain the Activity Share Yellow Yaks and Zebra Zooms. Today we will read a book about the letters Yy and a book about the letters Zz.
Read Read aloud Yellow Yaks with the following prompt.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Touch your nose when you hear a word that begins with the /y/ sound.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Read Read aloud Zebra Zooms with the following prompt.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Tap your head when you hear a word that begins with /z/.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Model Model writing uppercase and lowercase letters Yy and Zz. Provide drawing and writing supplies. Guide children in practicing forming their letters.

As you read Yellow Yaks, stop at each word that begins with the letter Yy. Have children say /y/ and the word that begins with y. Repeat with Zebra Zooms and the letter z. For children who need assistance, before writing have them trace letters in trays of salt or sand.

For a challenge, after reading each story, ask children to try to remember all the words that begin with the target sound and letter. Then invite them to name or draw any other words they know that begin with that letter and sound.

Be aware that children whose first language is Spanish may think of Yy and Ii as making the same sound—/ē/. Take extra time, as needed, to review the sounds those letters make in English, both in isolation and in the context of a picture word.

To help children with auditory discrimination challenges, exaggerate the movements of your mouth as you form each letter sound, being mindful of your tongue and lip positions. Do this while saying the sound in isolation and again as you say the sound within the picture word. Invite children to move their mouths in the same way as they make the letter sound.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Gather Materials Activity Cards, toys—fox, dog, snake, cat, goat, paper bag

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Today we read What Am I? We talked about using our working memory to remember the clues to answer the question Who Am I? We also listened for words that rhyme.
When we use our working memory, we hold information in our minds and use it to solve problems.
Remember that when two words rhyme, they end with the same sounds. Do wig and pig rhyme? Do bed and red rhyme?
Today we’ll look at pictures and rhyme words, and answer a “What Am I?” question. Then we’ll use our working memory to figure out if two words rhyme.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Ask Show one picture card at a time. Ask the questions on the back of the card, offering help as needed.
Extend Ask the riddle at the bottom of the card.
Set Up Next place the cards with the pictures face down on the table. Put the toy animals in a bag. Have one child choose an animal.
Match Which picture do you remember has a name that rhymes with your animal’s name? When the child guesses correctly, turn over the card, and together say “ rhymes with .”
Repeat Continue until all rhymes are correctly matched. Rhyming pairs are: box/fox, log/dog, rake/snake, hat/cat, boat/goat.
Talk About the Rhymes Break the sounds into onset and rime to explain why the two words rhyme. For example, /b/.../ox/ and /f/.../ox/ rhyme because they both end with /ox/.

If children need help identifying the ending sounds in words, repeat the words for them, one right after the other, for best comparison. When they find a rhyming pair, celebrate by adding real or nonsense rhymes from the same word family, such as box, fox, nox, pox, socks.

Challenge children to use the same cards to do the activity, but this time naming as many words as they know that rhyme (for example: hog/dog/bog/fog/jog/log). Children may offer more advanced rhymes, such as frog/smog/clog.

Invite multilingual learners to share rhymes they know from their home language. These can include songs and poems the child enjoys. This exchange will benefit everyone because the concept of rhyme is not language-specific but rather sound-specific. It is beneficial for all children to practice rhyming words, including words from another language.

Working memory activities may be difficult for children with attention challenges. The activity gets particularly challenging when children try to remember pictures that are facedown. If children become frustrated or disengage, encourage them to say the name of each toy animal and keep the cards face up for them.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Gather Materials play clay, index cards, markers

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Today we read What Am I? We saw how animals use their features to keep themselves safe.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Explain the Activity Recall with children the ways animals keep themselves safe. What did the snail use to keep itself safe? What did the chameleon use to keep itself safe? What did the shark keep itself safe? Today you will be making your own animals. You can make real animals or imaginary animals. Remember to make a special feature that will keep the animal safe.
Do the Activity As children create their animals, ask them to name the animal they are making and tell what feature will help to keep the animal safe.
Extend When they finish, help children write labels on cards with a name for the real or imaginary animal. Invite them to show their animals and tell about them.

Talk About Staying Safe We saw animals in the book and talked about how they stay safe. Then we made our own animals. Display all the animals in an Animal Museum. Invite children to view the collection and talk about the animals and their features.
Before children begin, do a picture walk through the book to remind them of the different animals that they saw. Point out the distinguishing features that the animals use to stay safe.

Challenge children to discuss these questions: What things do we wear to stay safe when we ride bikes? What things do we use to stay safe when we ride in cars? How does wearing bright colors help keep joggers and runners safe?

Invite multilingual learners to name their animals in their home language and in English. Label their animals with the name in both languages. When children discuss the animals in the Animal Museum, help children state their ideas by giving sentence starters, such as “This animal has .”
Some children need visual support and will benefit from using play clay with high-contrasting colors. Suggest they use the contrasting color to focus on the feature that is keeping the animal safe.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Gather Materials Activity Cards, masking tape to divide table, art supplies

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Today we read “Fantastic Feet.” We saw animals that have one foot, two feet, and four feet.

In this activity we will sort animal feet into two groups. I will show you a picture of an animal, and you will tell me if the animal has two feet or four feet. Then we will put all the animals with two feet on one side of the table and the animals with four feet on the other side.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Ask Show one picture card at a time. Ask the questions on the back of the card, offering help as needed.
Extend Use the last question to help children notice other features of each animal.
Do the Activity Show one card and ask children to tell how many feet the animal has. Guide one child to place the picture of the animal on one side of the table.
Repeat Continue until all the pictures are correctly sorted.

Talk About Fantastic Feet Invite children to talk about how each animal has feet that help it move in its habitat. Ask silly questions to encourage thinking: How would zebras run if they had only had two feet? How would parrots hold on to a branch if they had four feet? Invite children to draw a picture of the animal they liked best.

Children may find it easier to count the animal feet using models. So do the activity using toys. Show a toy lion and count the feet together. Show a toy bird and count the number of feet. Then sort the animals on either side of the table.
Challenge children to think of other animals that have two feet or four feet. Have children draw a picture of some of the animals and add the pictures to either side of the table.

Review each animal on the cards and its name. Point to the feet and ask: Does a duck have two feet? Provide a sentence frame for children and have them repeat: Yes, a duck has two feet. Practicing sentence structure and new vocabulary will help children feel more confident when they speak.
Provide children with a bin of plastic farm animals. Choose an animal and talk about the number of feet it has. Ask: Does it have two feet? Does it have four feet?
